TEI.2.document_title: Stephen F Austin to Nathaniel Cox, 04-02-1833

barker_notes.barker_summary: Austin to Nathaniel Cox, April 2, 1833. Gratified at Cox's approval of his settlement with the Hawkins heirs. Thinks Texas will be separated from Coahuila.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 940-941

*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to Nathaniel Cox, April 2, 1833. Gratified at Cox's approval of his settlement with the Hawkins heirs. Thinks Texas will be separated from Coahuila.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*San Felipe de Austin */location_mentioned**date_mentioned n="04-02-1833">April 2d, 1833*/date_mentioned**/p* *p**person_mentioned*Mr. N. Cox*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p*Dr Sir. I reed, your esteemed favor of *date_mentioned n="03-01-1833">1 ult.*/date_mentioned* recommending *person_mentioned*Doctor Spaulding*/person_mentioned* It will give me great pleasure to do any thing in my power to promote the views of the *person_mentioned*Docter*/person_mentioned*. He stoped at *location_mentioned*Matagorda*/location_mentioned* and I have not yet had the pleasure of seeing him.*/p*
*p*It is highly gratifying to me that you and *person_mentioned*Mr. Sanders*/person_mentioned* approve of my conduct in relation to the settlement of the business of our mutual friend *person_mentioned*J. H. Hawkins' estate*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*After the many years of labor and hardships and perplexities I have undergone in this *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*by which I have secured a handsome fortune for the *person_mentioned*heirs*/person_mentioned*, I was not prepared to receive censure from any of them, because I thought that I did not merit it. *person_mentioned*Edmund*/person_mentioned*, I fear, received incorrect impressions from some persons who are unfriendly to me, but I think they are removed now and that he is very well satisfied*/p*.
*p*It would be gratifying for me to receive assurances from *person_mentioned*Mr. Haws*/person_mentioned*, and from *person_mentioned*Geo. N. Hawkins*/person_mentioned* that they were satisfied with the settlement and with my conduct I have always viewed *person_mentioned*J. H. Hawkins*/person_mentioned* more like a brother than any thing else. I am however well aware that it is very difficult for persons at a distance, who live in a well organised *location_mentioned*community */location_mentioned*to form a correct idea of the trouble, or labor, or difficulties of doing business in this *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*of the kind I have been engaged in.*/p*
*p*Your approbation is very gratifying indeed for I prise your opinions very highly.*/p*
*p*I am endeavoring to close all my affairs and totally withdraw myself from public matters or politics—it is not so easy to do, as at first appeard.*/p*
*p*Our convention has met and will no doubt apply to the*person_mentioned* national congress */person_mentioned*for the admission of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*into the *location_mentioned*mexican union */location_mentioned*as a *location_mentioned*State*/location_mentioned*. I think the application will be granted. I believe it is very necessary to save this *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*from ruin. We are now able to sustain A *person_mentioned*State Govt*/person_mentioned*, and no *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*ever required one more than this.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*S. F. Austin */person_mentioned*[Rubric]*/p*
*/div1*
